metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Javascript operators are used to perform different types of mathematical and logical computations.
content.html: Javascript operators are used to perform different types of mathematical and logical computations.
The Assignment Operator = assigns values
The Addition Operator + adds values
The Multiplication Operator * multiplies values
The Comparison Operator > compares values

content.text: The Assignment Operator ( = ) assigns a value to a variable:
content.html: The Assignment Operator (=) assigns a value to a variable:

content.code_html: let x = 10;

content.html: The Addition Operator (+) adds numbers:

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x + y;

content.html: The Multiplication Operator (*) multiplies numbers:

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 2;
let z = x * y;

content.text: There are different types of JavaScript operators:
content.html: There are different types of JavaScript operators:

content.text: Arithmetic Operators are used to perform arithmetic on numbers:
content.html: Arithmetic Operators are used to perform arithmetic on numbers:

content.code_html:
let a = 3;
let x = (100 + 50) * a;

content.text: Arithmetic operators are fully described in the JS Arithmetic chapter.
content.html: Arithmetic operators are fully described in the JS Arithmetic chapter.

content.text: Assignment operators assign values to JavaScript variables.
content.html: Assignment operators assign values to JavaScript variables.

content.text: The Addition Assignment Operator ( += ) adds a value to a variable.
content.html: The Addition Assignment Operator (+=) adds a value to a variable.

content.code_html:
let x = 10;
x += 5;

Operator Example Same As
= x = y x = y
+= x += y x = x + y
-= x -= y x = x - y
*= x *= y x = x * y
/= x /= y x = x / y
%= x %= y x = x % y
**= x **= y x = x ** y

content.text: Assignment operators are fully described in the JS Assignment chapter.
content.html: Assignment operators are fully described in the JS Assignment chapter.

content.code_html:
Operator Description
== equal to
=== equal value and equal type
!= not equal
!== not equal value or not equal type
> greater than
< less than
>= greater than or equal to
<= less than or equal to
? ternary operator

content.text: Comparison operators are fully described in the JS Comparisons chapter.
content.html: Comparison operators are fully described in the JS Comparisons chapter.

content.text: All the comparison operators above can also be used on strings:
content.html: All the comparison operators above can also be used on strings:

content.code_html:
let text1 = "A";
let text2 = "B";
let result = text1 < text2;

content.text: Note that strings are compared alphabetically:
content.html: Note that strings are compared alphabetically:

content.code_html:
let text1 = "20";
let text2 = "5";
let result = text1 < text2;

content.text: The + can also be used to add (concatenate) strings:
content.html: The + can also be used to add (concatenate) strings:

content.code_html:
let text1 = "John";
let text2 = "Doe";
let text3 = text1 + " " + text2;

content.text: The += assignment operator can also be used to add (concatenate) strings:
content.html: The += assignment operator can also be used to add (concatenate) strings:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let text1 = "What a very ";
text1 += "nice day";

content.code:
let text1 = "What a very ";
text1 += "nice day";

syntax_highlighting.text:
let text1 = "What a very ";
text1 += "nice day";

content.code_html:
let text1 = "What a very ";
text1 += "nice day";

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let text1 = "What a very ";
text1 += "nice day";

content.text: When used on strings, the + operator is called the concatenation operator.
content.html: When used on strings, the + operator is called the concatenation operator.

content.text: Adding two numbers, will return the sum as a number like 5 + 5 = 10.
content.html: Adding two numbers, will return the sum as a number like 5 + 5 = 10.

content.text: Adding a number and a string, will return the sum as a concatenated string like 5 + "5" = "55".
content.html: Adding a number and a string, will return the sum as a concatenated string like 5 + "5" = "55".

content.code_html:
let x = 5 + 5;
let y = "5" + 5;
let z = "Hello" + 5;

content.text: If you add a number and a string, the result will be a string!
content.html: If you add a number and a string, the result will be a string!

content.code_html:
Operator Description
&& logical and
|| logical or
! logical not

content.text: Logical operators are fully described in the JS Comparisons chapter.
content.html: Logical operators are fully described in the JS Comparisons chapter.

content.code_html:
Operator Description
typeof Returns the type of a variable
instanceof Returns true if an object is an instance of an object type

content.text: Type operators are fully described in the JS Type Conversion chapter.
content.html: Type operators are fully described in the JS Type Conversion chapter.

content.text: Bit operators work on 32 bits numbers.
content.html: Bit operators work on 32 bits numbers.

content.code_html:
Operator Description Example Same as Result Decimal
& AND 5 & 1 0101 & 0001 0001  1
| OR 5 | 1 0101 | 0001 0101  5
~ NOT ~ 5  ~0101 1010  10
^ XOR 5 ^ 1 0101 ^ 0001 0100  4
<< left shift 5 << 1 0101 << 1 1010  10
>> right shift 5 >> 1 0101 >> 1 0010   2
>>> unsigned right shift 5 >>> 1 0101 >>> 1 0010   2

content.text: The examples above uses 4 bits unsigned examples. But JavaScript uses 32-bit signed numbers. Because of this, in JavaScript, ~ 5 will not return 10. It will return -6. ~00000000000000000000000000000101 will return 11111111111111111111111111111010
content.html:
The examples above uses 4 bits unsigned examples. But JavaScript uses 32-bit signed numbers.
Because of this, in JavaScript, ~ 5 will not return 10. It will return -6.
~00000000000000000000000000000101 will return 11111111111111111111111111111010

content.text: Bitwise operators are fully described in the JS Bitwise chapter.
content.html: Bitwise operators are fully described in the JS Bitwise chapter.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let x = 5; let y = '8'; let z = x + y; What will be the result of z ?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let x = 5;
let y = '8';
let z = x + y;
What will be the result of z?

metadata.question: Consider the following code:let x = 5;let y = '8';let z = x + y;What will be the result of z?

content.question: Consider the following code:let x = 5;let y = '8';let z = x + y;What will be the result of z?
